questions.text: Identify the procedure shown in the image: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intra uterine balloon tamponade

 

The image shows an intrauterine balloon tamponade procedure, which is a mechanical method used to treat atonic postpartum hemorrhage. The illustration depicts a uterus with a balloon inserted into it, which is being filled with saline. This procedure creates pressure within the uterine cavity to compress bleeding vessels and control hemorrhage. The Bakri balloon is specifically designed for this purpose, though alternatives like condom catheters or Foley's catheters can also be used in resource-limited settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometrial ablation: This procedure uses a much smaller balloon and includes a thermal system to destroy the endometrial lining. 

 

Option C. Cervical ripening: This involves placing prostaglandin E2 gel (Dinoprostone) in the endocervical canal, not within the uterine cavity.

 

Option D. Parachute pack: A parachute pack, also known as a Logothetopoulos pack, is a transvaginal packing technique used to control bleeding after a hysterectomy or other obstetric procedures. It's used to compress bleeding areas against the pelvic bone and fascia. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Appearance and understand the use of intrauterine balloon tamponade as a mechanical method for managing postpartum hemorrhage.

choices.text: Suicidal firearm wounds
Traumatic asphyxia
Drowning
Electrocution

questions.text: Cadaveric spasm is seen in all except: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Traumatic asphyxia

 

Option B. Traumatic Asphyxia : This condition typically results from a severe crush injury to the chest or abdomen that prevents normal respiration. Cadaveric spasms are less likely because the death does not involve a sudden catastrophic nervous system event that would induce immediate muscle contraction.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Suicidal Firearm Wounds : Cadaveric spasm may occur in cases of suicidal firearm wounds due to the intense muscle contraction at the moment of death. The individual might be holding a weapon tightly, which can lead to a cadaveric spasm preserving the grip on the firearm.

 

Option C. Drowning : Cadaveric spasm can occur during drowning as the individual may be holding onto objects or vegetation in a panic, and these grips can become fixed due to the sudden cessation of brain function.

 

Option D. Electrocution : Electrocution can cause instantaneous and intense muscular contractions and possibly a cadaveric spasm. This can result in the deceased gripping onto any objects they were touching at the time of electrocution.

 

Educational objective :

 

Cadaveric spasm is a rare phenomenon usually associated with the sudden and intense activation of muscles at the time of death. It is most commonly seen in deaths involving intense emotional or physical stress where the muscle contraction occurs at or near the moment of death, such as in shootings, electrocution, or drowning.

questions.text: Eyelid crusting and gritty sensation between the lids is associated with: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chronic blepharitis

 

Explanation: 


Chronic blepharitis is a persistent inflammation of the eyelids characterized by:

 

  • Eyelid crusting (dried secretions along the eyelid margins)
  • Gritty sensation between the eyelids
  • Chronic discharge
  • Inflammation of the lid margins

 

The typical management includes:

 

  1. Oral doxycycline (100 mg twice daily)
  2. Topical antibiotics
  3. Lid hygiene: 
    • Cleaning lids with mild detergents (e.g., Johnson's baby shampoo)
    • Using hypochlorous solution
    • Frequent lid cleaning to remove crusts and debris

 

 

Other Options:


Option A. Conjunctivitis: Incorrect. While conjunctivitis can cause eye discomfort, it typically presents with more pronounced redness, discharge, and does not specifically cause eyelid crusting.

 

Option B. Dry eye syndrome: Incorrect. Dry eye syndrome causes discomfort and a gritty sensation, but does not typically result in significant eyelid crusting.

 

Option C. Meibomian gland dysfunction: Partially related, but not the most comprehensive answer. While meibomian gland dysfunction can contribute to blepharitis, chronic blepharitis encompasses a broader inflammatory condition of the eyelids.

 

Educational Objective: 


Chronic blepharitis is characterized by persistent eyelid inflammation, manifesting as crusting and a gritty sensation, requiring comprehensive management including oral antibiotics, topical treatments, and rigorous lid hygiene.

questions.text: Among the listed muscle relaxants, which is primarily excreted via renal pathways? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pancuronium

 

Pancuronium is primarily excreted through the kidneys, with approximately 90% of the drug eliminated unchanged via renal excretion. Only 10-20% of pancuronium is metabolized in the liver, making renal clearance its dominant elimination pathway. This is why pancuronium is contraindicated in patients with renal failure, as impaired kidney function significantly prolongs its duration of action.

 

Table of Muscle Relaxant Elimination

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vecuronium: Incorrect because vecuronium has multiple elimination pathways. Only about 25% is excreted through the kidneys, while a significant amount (40%) is excreted in bile. Additionally, 30-40% of vecuronium is metabolized in the liver. 

 

Option C. Atracurium: Incorrect because atracurium undergoes a unique spontaneous degradation in plasma called Hoffman degradation, which is pH and temperature-dependent. This elimination pathway makes atracurium one of the muscle relaxants of choice for patients with renal failure since its clearance is independent of renal function.

 

Option D. Rocuronium: Incorrect because rocuronium is primarily eliminated through hepatic pathways (>70%), with minimal renal excretion.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Pancuronium is primarily eliminated through renal excretion (90%), making it absolutely contraindicated in patients with renal failure, while other commonly used muscle relaxants have significant non-renal elimination pathways.

questions.text: The relationship between two variables that is attributed to a shared third factor is referred to as: [NEET PG 2016]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Indirect association

 

  • When two variables appear to be associated but their relationship is actually due to a shared third factor, this is an indirect association.
  • In this situation, there is no true causal relationship between the two variables themselves - instead, both are related to a common third factor. 
  • â€˜This third factor (the common factor) is also known as a "confounding variable."
  • Indirect association occurs when there's a statistical association between a characteristic and a disease due to the presence of another factor that is common to both. The relationship appears to exist only because both variables are independently linked to this third factor, not because they directly influence each other.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spurious association: Incorrect A spurious association is completely false or artificial - it's an apparent association that doesn't actually exist but appears due to errors in study design, data collection, or interpretation. Unlike indirect association, there is no real connection between the variables, even through a third factor.

 

Option C. Direct association: Incorrect Direct (causal) association means one variable directly affects or influences the other. This is the opposite of the scenario described in the question, where the relationship is mediated through a third factor rather than being direct.

 

Option D. Causal association: Incorrect Causal association is a type of direct association where one variable causes changes in the other. In the scenario described in the question, neither variable causes the other - they are both affected by a shared third factor, making this an indirect rather than causal association.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the different types of associations is crucial in epidemiology - an indirect association exists when two variables appear related only because both are independently associated with a common third factor (confounding variable).

questions.text: Identify the range of the firearm wound: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Close Shot Entry Wound

 

  • Lot of blackening is easily visible around the firearm wound in the image.
  • Burning, blackening and tattooing are the features of entry wound. They are not found in exit wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Close shot exit wound: Exit wounds typically do not exhibit burning, blackening, or tattooing. They are generally larger and more irregular than entry wounds.

 

Option C. Distant shot entry wound: Distant shot entry wounds lack the features of burning, blackening, and tattooing. The wound edges are usually cleaner.

 

Option D. Distant shot exit wound: Similar to close shot exit wounds, distant shot exit wounds do not have burning, blackening, or tattooing and are typically larger and more irregular.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Entry Wound features:

 

  1. Contact Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present just on the margin; not around the wound. Very minimally visible.
  2. Close Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent)
  3. Intermediate Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound
  4. Distant range: None of these present around the wound.

questions.text: A patient with mild to moderate renal failure requires reversal of muscle relaxation induced by vecuronium. Which of the following drugs is appropriate for this purpose? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sugammadex

 

Vecuronium is a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant used during surgeries to facilitate intubation and muscle relaxation. After the procedure, it is often necessary to reverse the effects of vecuronium to allow the patient to regain muscle function.

 

Sugammadex is a selective relaxant binding agent (SRBA) specifically designed to reverse the effects of certain non-depolarizing muscle relaxants, including vecuronium and rocuronium. It works by encapsulating the vecuronium molecules, effectively reducing their availability to bind to nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction, thereby reversing muscle paralysis.

 

Sugammadex is preferred in patients with mild to moderate renal failure because it is highly effective and works faster than traditional agents like neostigmine. While Sugammadex is contraindicated in severe or end-stage renal disease due to reduced clearance, it can be safely used in mild to moderate renal impairment.

 

Note –

 

Reversal agents for muscle relaxants used in anesthesia include neostigmine and Sugammadex.

 

Neostigmine:

 

  • A cholinergic drug that inhibits acetylcholinesterase, leading to increased acetylcholine.
  • Causes cholinergic side effects due to the increased acetylcholine.
  • Can be used for all muscle relaxants.
  • Can be given in renal disease patients
  • If neostigmine is not an option and the patient has mild to moderate renal failure, Sugammadex is the preferred choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Physostigmine: Physostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, but it is primarily used to reverse the effects of central nervous system depressants and is not typically used for reversing non-depolarizing muscle relaxants like vecuronium.

 

Option B. Rivastigmine: Rivastigmine is also an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, but it is used in the management of Alzheimer's disease and other types of dementia, not for reversing muscle relaxants.

 

Option D. Succinylcholine: Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant used for short-term muscle relaxation, such as during intubation. It is not used for reversing the effects of non-depolarizing muscle relaxants like vecuronium and, in fact, would induce more muscle relaxation rather than reverse it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sugammadex is the appropriate agent for reversing the effects of vecuronium in patients with mild to moderate renal failure due to its specific action on non-depolarizing muscle relaxants and its faster onset of action.

choices.text: Lateral rectus > Superior rectus > Medial rectus > Inferior rectus
Medial rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus > Inferior rectus
Medial rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus
Superior rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Medial rectus

questions.text: What is the correct order of insertion of muscles from near to far from the limbus?(FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Medial rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus

 

This order represents the correct sequence of insertion of the extraocular muscles from near to far from the limbus, which is the border between the cornea and the sclera of the eye. The medial rectus inserts closest to the limbus, around 5.5mm, followed by the inferior rectus, which inserts at 6.5mm; the lateral rectus at 6.9mm and the superior rectus inserts farthest from the limbus, which is 7.7mm. The spiral formed by joining the insertion points of the four recti muscles is referred to as the Spiral of Tillaux

 

 

  • Medial rectus: This muscle is located closest to the limbus among the options provided. It inserts on the sclera of the eye near the medial aspect.
  • Inferior rectus: Following the medial rectus, the inferior rectus muscle inserts on the sclera near the lower aspect of the eye, hence moving away from the limbus.
  • Lateral rectus: Next in the sequence is the lateral rectus muscle, which inserts on the lateral aspect of the sclera, farther away from the limbus compared to the medial and inferior rectus muscles.
  • Superior rectus: Lastly, the superior rectus muscle inserts on the sclera near the upper aspect of the eye, making it farthest from the limbus among the muscles listed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct order of insertion of the extraocular muscles from near to far from the limbus is: Medial rectus > Inferior rectus > Lateral rectus > Superior rectus

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a lump in the upper outer quadrant of her breast. Histopathological examination of the mass showed cells in mucin pools and faint nuclei. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Colloid carcinoma

 

The given scenario is suggestive of colloid or mucinous carcinoma of the breast.

 

This is a rare type of breast cancer that occurs more frequently in older women and grows slowly. The prognosis of colloid carcinoma is better than that of infiltrating duct carcinoma.

 

The tumor is typically a soft, gelatinous mass with well-defined borders.

 

Histologically, colloid carcinoma has a lot of extracellular epithelial mucin and mucin-filled acini. Floating in large lakes of mucin are cuboidal to tall columnar tumor cells, some of which show mucus vacuolation. Nuclei in intracellular type are pushed to the periphery, forming a signet ring appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Papillary carcinoma: Papillary carcinoma of the breast is characterized by the presence of papillary structures lined by neoplastic cells.

 

  • It does not typically present with large pools of mucin.

 

Option C. Medullary carcinoma: Medullary carcinoma is characterized by large, high-grade cells with a syncytial growth pattern, prominent lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate, and pushing borders.

 

  • It lacks the extensive mucin pools seen in colloid carcinoma.

 

Option D. Lobular carcinoma: Lobular carcinoma is characterized by small, uniform cells arranged in single-file lines or targetoid patterns.

 

  • It typically lacks the mucin pools characteristic of colloid carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Colloid carcinoma of the breast, also known as mucinous carcinoma, is identified by the presence of tumor cells floating in large extracellular mucin pools. This rare type of breast cancer has a better prognosis compared to infiltrating duct carcinoma and is characterized histologically by its mucinous components.

questions.text: A patient following a road traffic accident was brought to the emergency by the family members. His CT scan was done which showed the following image. Which of the following can be given to this patient in this situation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin K

 

The CT scan image shows a subdural hematoma (SDH), which is a type of intracranial hemorrhage characterized by a crescent-shaped bleed along the brain's surface, often resulting from head trauma. In the case of traumatic intracranial hemorrhage, the primary concern is to stop the bleeding and manage intracranial pressure.

 

Vitamin K is an essential factor in the clotting cascade and is used to promote clotting and reduce bleeding. It is especially useful if the patient is suspected to be on anticoagulant therapy, as it helps counteract the effects of such medications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alteplase: Alteplase is a thrombolytic agent used to dissolve clots in ischemic stroke or myocardial infarction. Administering it in the context of a hemorrhagic stroke would worsen the bleeding.

 

Option B. Retiplase: Similar to alteplase, retiplase is another thrombolytic agent and is contraindicated in cases of hemorrhage due to its potential to exacerbate bleeding.

 

Option D. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant that prevents clot formation. Giving heparin in a situation of intracranial hemorrhage would further inhibit clotting and worsen the bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the event of a traumatic intracranial hemorrhage, such as a subdural hematoma, Vitamin K is administered to promote blood clotting and reduce further bleeding, especially if the patient is on anticoagulant therapy.

questions.text: In a patient with Horner syndrome, ptosis is most likely due to paralysis of which of the following muscles? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Superior tarsal muscle

 

The superior tarsal muscle, also known as Muller's muscle, is a smooth muscle that assists in elevating the upper eyelid. In Horner syndrome, there is damage to the sympathetic nerve supply, specifically the T1 nerve, which innervates the superior tarsal muscle. Paralysis of this muscle leads to ptosis, or drooping of the upper eyelid, because the muscle cannot perform its function of aiding eyelid elevation. Horner syndrome typically results from a disruption in the sympathetic nerves, leading to symptoms like ptosis, miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (lack of sweating).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbitalis: This muscle provides support to the eyeball from the back. In Horner syndrome, although the orbitalis muscle may be affected, leading to a sunken appearance of the eyeball (apparent enophthalmos), it does not contribute directly to ptosis.

 

Option B. Levator superioris palpebrae: This muscle is primarily responsible for the elevation of the eyelid. However, it is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III), not by the sympathetic nervous system, and its paralysis leads to significant ptosis, but this condition is unrelated to Horner syndrome.

 

Option C. Orbicularis Oculi: This muscle is responsible for closing the eyelid and is innervated by the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). Paralysis of this muscle leads to inability to close the eyelid but is not involved in ptosis due to Horner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Horner syndrome is characterized by ptosis due to paralysis of the superior tarsal muscle (Muller's muscle), which is innervated by sympathetic fibers, particularly from the T1 spinal nerve

questions.text: Which of the following antibodies is diagnostic for mixed connective tissue disease? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. U1-RNP antibody

 

Explanation: 

 

Mixed connective tissue disease is characterized by high titers of antibodies to U1 ribonucleoprotein (U1-RNP). This antibody is considered diagnostic for the condition, which presents with clinical features that overlap with those of SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. Patients typically present with synovitis of the fingers, Raynaud phenomenon, myositis, and renal involvement, which usually responds well to corticosteroids, at least in the short term.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-nuclear antibody - While anti-nuclear antibodies (ANAs) are present in mixed connective tissue disease, they are not specific for this condition. ANAs are found in many autoimmune diseases including SLE, systemic sclerosis, and SjÃ¶gren syndrome, so their presence alone cannot differentiate mixed connective tissue disease from other connective tissue disorders.

 

Option B. SCL-70 antibody - SCL-70 antibody (anti-DNA topoisomerase I) is associated with systemic sclerosis (scleroderma), particularly the diffuse cutaneous form with increased risk of pulmonary fibrosis and peripheral vascular disease. It is not characteristic of mixed connective tissue disease.

 

Option D. Anti-CCP antibody - Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies are highly specific for rheumatoid arthritis. They are not typically found in mixed connective tissue disease and are used to differentiate rheumatoid arthritis from other forms of inflammatory arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High titres of antibodies to U1 ribonucleoprotein (U1-RNP) are the serological hallmark and diagnostic marker for mixed connective tissue disease, a condition with overlapping features of several autoimmune disorders including SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis.

questions.text: A particular community population has been consuming Maize as a staple diet for years. The vitamin deficiency most likely to be seen in this population is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Niacin

 

Maize, commonly consumed as a staple food in many communities, is deficient in the amino acid tryptophan, which is crucial for the synthesis of niacin (Vitamin B3) in the body. Niacin can be synthesized endogenously from tryptophan at a conversion rate of 60 mg of tryptophan to 1 mg of niacin. However, when maize is a primary dietary component, the body lacks sufficient tryptophan, leading to niacin deficiency.

 

Moreover, maize is high in leucine, an amino acid that inhibits the conversion of tryptophan to niacin via the kynurenine pathway. This combination of low tryptophan and high leucine content makes niacin deficiency prevalent in populations consuming maize as a staple diet, resulting in pellagra.

 

Pellagra is characterized by the â€œ4 Dsâ€: Diarrhea, Dermatitis, Dementia, and Death if untreated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiamine: Thiamine deficiency is typically associated with polished rice consumption, not maize. It leads to conditions like beriberi.

 

Option B. Riboflavin: Riboflavin deficiency, though possible, is not specifically linked to maize consumption. It typically results from general dietary insufficiency of various foods, not specific to maize.

 

Option D. Cyanocobalamin: Cyanocobalamin (Vitamin B12) deficiency is generally seen in populations with low intake of animal products and is not related to maize consumption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Maize as a staple diet leads to niacin deficiency due to its low tryptophan and high leucine content, resulting in pellagra.

 

Note â€“ Leucine is known as pellagrogenic aminoacid in India

choices.text: LH from maternal pituitary
HCG from placenta
Inhibin from corpus luteum
GnRH from fetal hypothalamus

questions.text: Testosterone helps in the development of various organs in the fetus. Which of the following stimulates its production? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HCG from placenta

 

Explanation:

 

  • HCG from placenta:
    • HCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) from the placenta stimulates the production of testosterone in the male fetus.
    • HCG released from the placenta is the initial stimulus for testosterone production in the male fetus.
    • Later by the eighth week of gestation, fetal pituitary LH (luteinizing hormone) stimulates the Leydig cells of the testes to produce testosterone.
    • Sex differentiation of the embryo depends on the Y chromosome, which contains the testis-determining gene called the SRY (sex-determining region on Y) gene.
    • In a genetically male embryo (46, XY), the gonad is converted into testis under the influence of this gene.
    • Female development (Mullerian ducts) occurs in the absence of this gene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LH from maternal pituitary: Maternal LH does not play a role in fetal testosterone production. The fetal pituitary gland, not the maternal pituitary, influences testosterone production later in gestation.

 

Option C. Inhibin from corpus luteum: Inhibin is involved in the regulation of FSH and does not stimulate testosterone production. It primarily acts to provide feedback inhibition to the anterior pituitary gland to control FSH levels.

 

Option D. GnRH from fetal hypothalamus: GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone) from the fetal hypothalamus plays a role in stimulating the fetal pituitary to release LH and FSH, but it is not the initial trigger for testosterone production in the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HCG from the placenta is the initial stimulus for testosterone production in the male fetus.

 

Ref: Page 103, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: The most radiosensitive phase of the cell cycle is: (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) G2 phase

 

Each phase of the cell cycle exhibits different levels of sensitivity to radiation damage:

 

This is the second gap phase after DNA synthesis where the cell prepares for mitosis. Cells in the G2 phase are more sensitive to radiation than those in the G1 and S phases, as the cell checks for DNA damage and repairs it before proceeding to mitosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. M Phase (Mitosis): This is the phase where the cell divides into two daughter cells.. The cell's machinery is entirely focused on the mitotic process, making it less able to repair DNA damage effectively.

 

Option C. S Phase: During this phase, DNA replication occurs. Cells are more resistant to radiation in the S phase because the DNA is actively being synthesized, and the repair processes are robust.

 

Option D. G1 Phase: This is the first gap phase, where cells increase in size and prepare the necessary components for DNA synthesis. Cells in the G1 phase are relatively resistant to radiation compared to other phases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most radiosensitive phase of the cell cycle is the G2-> M  (G2>M) phase. During this phase cells are particularly vulnerable to radiation because any damage caused during this phase can lead to immediate catastrophic errors in cell division, leading to cell death.

questions.text: While performing epidural anaesthesia which of these layers is not punctured ? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arachnoid mater

 

Explanation:

 

For epidural anesthesia, the needle is inserted through several layers before reaching the epidural space, which is just outside the dura mater. The arachnoid mater is a delicate membrane that encloses the cerebrospinal fluid and runs just under the dura mater. In epidural anesthesia, the arachnoid mater is not punctured, as this would mean the needle has gone too deep, entering the subarachnoid (intrathecal) space.

 

Layers pierced for Epidural anesthesia (from outside to inside):

 

  1. Skin, subcutaneous tissue
  2. Supraspinous ligament
  3. Interspinous ligament
  4. Ligamentum flavum
  5. Epidural space

 

  • Structures pierced during spinal anesthesia / lumbar puncture (outside to inside): Skin, subcutaneous fat, supraspinous ligament, interspinous ligament, ligamentum flavum, duramater, arachnoid mater.
  • Last structure to be pierced during epidural anesthesia : Ligamentum flavum
  • Last structure to be pierced during spinal anesthesia / lumbar puncture: Arachnoid mater

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ligamentum Flavum: This is a strong ligament that connects the laminae of the vertebrae. It is the last ligamentous layer that the needle passes through before entering the epidural space.

 

Option C. Supraspinous Ligament: This is a strong, fibrous cord that connects the tips of the spinous processes from the seventh cervical vertebra to the sacrum. This ligament is pierced as the needle progresses towards the epidural space.

 

Option D. Interspinous Ligament: This ligament lies immediately below the supraspinous ligament and connects the adjoining spinous processes to each other. The needle also traverses this ligament as it moves toward the epidural space.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The arachnoid mater is not punctured during epidural anesthesia; penetration of this layer indicates a breach into the subarachnoid space, which is not the target for an epidural block.

choices.text: Respiratory rate more than 18 per min
Urine output less than 60 ml in 4 hours

questions.text: A patient of eclampsia is being treated with magnesium sulfate. Which of the following is an indication to stop this drug? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urine output less than 60 ml in 4 hours

 

Magnesium sulfate is commonly used to prevent seizures in patients with eclampsia. However, it has a narrow therapeutic window, meaning the difference between a therapeutic dose and a toxic dose is small. Therefore, careful monitoring is essential to avoid magnesium toxicity.

 

Key indicators to monitor during magnesium sulfate therapy include:

 

  • Urine output: Magnesium is excreted by the kidneys, so adequate urine output is necessary to prevent accumulation and toxicity. A urine output of less than 100 ml in last 4 hours (or 25 ml/hr) is concerning, but in this question, the threshold given is 60 ml in 4 hours. This reduced output is a sign that the kidneys are not excreting magnesium effectively, indicating a risk for toxicity, and the drug should be stopped.
  • Respiratory rate: Magnesium sulfate can cause respiratory depression. If the respiratory rate drops below 12 breaths per minute, it is a sign of potential magnesium toxicity and an indication to stop the drug.
  • Deep tendon reflexes: Magnesium sulfate can diminish or abolish deep tendon reflexes. The absence of reflexes is one of the first clinical signs of toxicity. Exaggerated reflexes would not be seen with magnesium toxicity; rather, they would be diminished.
  • Cardiac Problems â€“ in late stages

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respiratory rate more than 18 per min: An increased respiratory rate is not a concern for magnesium toxicity. The concern arises when the respiratory rate is decreased below 12 breaths per minute.

 

Option B. Exaggerated deep tendon reflexes: Magnesium toxicity is associated with diminished or abolished reflexes, not exaggerated ones.

 

Option D. Presence of visual disturbances: Visual disturbances are not typically related to magnesium sulfate toxicity, and thus are not an indication to stop the medication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

During magnesium sulfate therapy, urine output should be monitored carefully, and a significant reduction in output (less than 60 ml in 4 hours) is an indication to stop the drug to prevent toxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best level of prevention of breast cancer? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Early diagnosis and treatment

 

Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial in the management of breast cancer. This involves screening methods such as mammography, which can detect cancer at an early stage when it is more likely to be treated successfully. Early treatment can significantly improve survival rates and outcomes for patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Specific protection: Specific protection involves preventive measures that protect against specific diseases, such as vaccinations or using protective equipment. Currently, there is no vaccine or specific protective measure that can prevent breast cancer.

 

Option C. Disability limitation: Disability limitation is part of tertiary prevention and focuses on minimizing the impact of an ongoing illness that has already caused some level of disability. It involves strategies to prevent complications and further disability. This is more applicable after a disease has been diagnosed and is not the best level of prevention for breast cancer.

 

Option D. Rehabilitation: Rehabilitation is also a part of tertiary prevention and aims to help individuals recover as much function as possible after a disease has caused disability. It includes therapies to restore physical, psychological, and social functioning. While important, it is not the best preventive strategy for breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Early diagnosis and treatment (secondary prevention) are the most effective methods for preventing the progression of breast cancer, as they allow for early detection and intervention, significantly improving the chances of successful treatment and reducing mortality rates.

questions.text: Mycoplasma is inherently resistant to which of the following antibiotics? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Beta lactam antibiotics

 

Mycoplasma is inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics.

 

Mycoplasma lack cell wall, and therefore, are inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics as these drugs act on the cell wall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Macrolides: Incorrect, as macrolides are effective against Mycoplasma. They work by inhibiting protein synthesis and are commonly used to treat infections caused by these bacteria.

 

Option C. Tetracycline: Incorrect, tetracyclines are also effective against Mycoplasma and work by inhibiting bacterial protein synthesis.

 

Option D. Fluoroquinolones: Incorrect, fluoroquinolones, which inhibit bacterial DNA synthesis, are effective against a broad range of bacteria, including Mycoplasma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The unique features of Mycoplasma is the absence of a cell wall, this is why beta-lactam antibiotics are not suitable for treating infections caused by Mycoplasma.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented with rhinitis and swelling of the face. Intranasal biopsy revealed the presence of broad-based aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching. There was evidence of vascular invasion. What will be the preferred treatment for this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Amphotericin B

 

The clinical presentation and biopsy findings of broad-based aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching and evidence of vascular invasion are characteristic of mucormycosis, a serious fungal infection commonly seen in diabetic patients and other immunocompromised individuals. Amphotericin B is the preferred initial treatment for mucormycosis due to its broad antifungal coverage and effectiveness against Mucorales, the group of fungi responsible for this infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluconazole: Fluconazole is an antifungal medication used primarily for Candida and Cryptococcus infections. It is not effective against Mucorales and therefore not suitable for treating mucormycosis.

 

Option C. Ketoconazole: Ketoconazole is another antifungal agent with a broad spectrum of action but has limited use due to its side effects and is not effective against Mucorales, making it inappropriate for mucormycosis treatment.

 

Option D. Griseofulvin: Griseofulvin is used for dermatophyte infections (e.g., tinea infections) and is not effective against Mucorales. It is not suitable for treating mucormycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of Mucormycosis:

 

  • Mucormycosis is a serious fungal infection that requires prompt and aggressive treatment due to its rapid progression and high mortality rate.
  • The mainstay of treatment is intravenous Amphotericin B, often followed by oral posaconazole or isavuconazole for maintenance therapy.
  • Surgical debridement of infected tissue is frequently necessary.
  • Controlling underlying conditions like diabetes is also crucial in managing mucormycosis.

questions.text: A person reported to OPD alongside his 32-year-old brother working in a factory. The brother was recently subjected to a test â€“ Coproporphyrin in urine. The physician should suspect: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Lead poisoning

 

The presence of coproporphyrin in urine is commonly associated with lead exposure, making it an important screening test for lead poisoning. Coproporphyrin in urine indicates exposure to lead, but it does not confirm whether significant absorption has occurred. To determine absorption, a specific diagnostic test called Aminolevulinic Acid in Urine (ALAU) is used.

 

CPU â€“ screening test â€“ indicates lead Exposure - >150 mcg/L

 

ALAU â€“ diagnostic test â€“ indicated lead absorption - > 5mg/L

 

Elevated levels of lead in urine (>800 Âµg/L) signify both exposure and absorption, while levels above 700 Âµg/L indicate the onset of clinical symptoms.

 

Lead poisoning, also known as plumbism, is treated with chelation therapy using EDTA combined with dimercaprol, which helps remove lead from the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Silicosis: Silicosis is a lung disease caused by inhaling silica dust, common in mining, quarrying, and glass manufacturing industries. It does not involve testing for coproporphyrin in urine.

 

Option B. Byssinosis: Byssinosis, also known as â€œbrown lung disease,â€ is caused by inhaling cotton, flax, or hemp dust, mainly affecting textile workers. It is unrelated to coproporphyrin levels in urine.

 

Option C. Bagassosis: Bagassosis is an occupational lung disease caused by inhaling dust from bagasse, the fibrous residue of sugarcane. This condition is not associated with lead exposure or coproporphyrin levels.

 

Educational Objective:


Coproporphyrin in urine is an important screening test for lead poisoning, indicating exposure to lead, and should be followed by diagnostic tests to assess absorption.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl was washing her doll with shampoo containing rotenone. Her mother noticed her in an unconscious state. Which is inhibited by the above chemical? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NADH dehydrogenase

 

Rotenone is a potent inhibitor of Complex I in the electron transport chain, which is also known as NADH dehydrogenase or NADH oxidoreductase. Complex I is responsible for transferring electrons from NADH to coenzyme Q (ubiquinone), a crucial step in cellular respiration and ATP production. By inhibiting Complex, I, rotenone disrupts the electron transport chain, leading to a significant reduction in ATP synthesis. This inhibition can result in decreased cellular energy and potential cellular damage, which explains the unconscious state observed in the child.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Succinate dehydrogenase: This enzyme is part of Complex II in the electron transport chain, which is not affected by rotenone. Complex II facilitates the transfer of electrons from succinate to coenzyme Q, bypassing Complex I, which is why rotenone does not inhibit this step.

 

Option C. Cytochrome C: Cytochrome C is a small heme protein that plays a role in electron transfer between Complex III and Complex IV of the electron transport chain. Rotenone does not affect Cytochrome C, as it acts upstream at Complex I.

 

Option D. Cytochrome oxidase: Also known as Complex IV, this enzyme is responsible for transferring electrons from Cytochrome C to oxygen, the final electron acceptor. Inhibitors of Complex IV include cyanide and carbon monoxide, not rotenone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rotenone specifically inhibits Complex I also known as NADH CoQ oxidoreductase (NADH dehydrogenase) in the electron transport chain, blocking electron flow and ATP production.

questions.text: A young man came to the medical OPD with complaints of early morning backache and stiffness, which improves on exercise, and persistent red eyes. On examination, lung expansion was less than 3 cm. X-ray is shown in the image given below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects the spine and sacroiliac joints, leading to pain and stiffness. The hallmark feature of AS is inflammatory back pain, which is characterized by pain and stiffness that are worse in the morning and improve with exercise. The persistent red eyes are indicative of anterior uveitis, a common extra-articular manifestation of AS.

 

The reduced lung expansion (less than 3 cm) points towards involvement of the thoracic spine, leading to restrictive lung disease due to reduced chest wall mobility. The X-ray image shows characteristic changes of AS, including syndesmophytes and the "bamboo spine" appearance, which result from the ossification of ligaments and entheses (where tendons and ligaments attach to the bone).

 

Bamboo spine

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paget's disease: This condition is characterized by abnormal bone remodeling but does not typically present with inflammatory back pain or extra-articular manifestations such as uveitis.

 

Option C. Healed tuberculosis: While tuberculosis can affect the spine (Pott's disease), it does not present with the classic inflammatory back pain or the characteristic radiographic changes seen in AS.

 

Option D. Osteopetrosis: This is a rare genetic disorder that leads to increased bone density and brittleness but does not present with the clinical and radiographic features of AS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ankylosing spondylitis should be suspected in young patients with inflammatory back pain that improves with exercise, reduced lung expansion, and extra-articular manifestations such as uveitis. The "bamboo spine" on X-ray is a characteristic finding in advanced cases of AS.

choices.text: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient presents with a history of loss of interest in day-to-day activities, weight loss, insomnia, and sadness for six months. She also recalls hearing a voice once that ordered her to kill herself. What is the DSM-V diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

 

The patient's symptoms of loss of interest in daily activities, weight loss, insomnia, and persistent sadness align with major depressive disorder. The presence of auditory hallucination (voice ordering her to commit suicide) indicates an additional psychotic feature. Hence, the diagnosis would be Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Schizophrenia: It is a chronic disorder typically lasting more than 6 months, with symptoms like delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, etc. without a predominant mood episode.

 

Option C. Schizoaffective disorder: It has features of both schizophrenia and mood disorders concurrently.

 

Option D. Delusional disorder: The primary feature is a persistent delusion without other symptoms of psychosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Psychotic depression In Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features (also known as psychotic depression), is seen in moderate to severe depressive disorder where the individual experiences both depressive symptoms and psychosis, such as delusions or hallucinations. These psychotic symptoms could be mood congruent (i.e, content of delusion/ hallucination is consistent with the depressed mood) or mood incongruent. Psychotic symptoms align with the mood episode's theme, differentiating it from schizoaffective disorder. Treatment includes typically combining antipsychotics with antidepressants.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadockâ€™s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 356, 360.

questions.text: In a given population, total births were 4050 including 50 stillbirths in a given year. 50 neonates die within the first 7 days of life, and an additional 150 die within 8-28 days of life. What is the Neonatal mortality rate in the population? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 50

 

The Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) is a key indicator of neonatal health and is calculated as the number of neonatal deaths per 1000 live births. The neonatal period spans from birth up to 28 days and is further divided into:

 

  • Early Neonatal Period: 0-7 days
  • Late Neonatal Period: 8-28 days

 

Calculation:

 

  • Total births: 4050 (including 50 stillbirths)
  • Neonatal deaths:
    • Early Neonatal Period: 50 deaths
    • Late Neonatal Period: 150 deaths
  • Total Neonatal Deaths: 50 + 150 = 200 deaths
  • Total Live Births: 4050 - 50 (stillbirths) = 4000 live births
  • Neonatal Mortality Rate Formula:

 

 

  • Calculate NMR

 

 

Thus, the Ans.  is 50 per 1000 live births.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Neonatal Mortality Rate (NMR) is calculated as the number of neonatal deaths per 1000 live births.
